title: Capacitors - how dielectric constant 2 affects E

content.question: Two parallel plates have charges of magnitude <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> and opposite sign, as shown in the figure labeled “Initial Configuration.” The capacitor plates are isolated and there is an electric field of magnitude <math alttext="E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> in between the plates. An insulating slab of material with a dielectric constant of <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is then inserted into the capacitor, completely filling the space between the plates, as shown in the figure labeled “Final Configuration.” How does the magnitude <math alttext="E sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> of the electric field between the plates in the final configuration compare to <math alttext="E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub f is less than E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. Some of the charge from each plate moves into the dielectric, resulting in less overall charge on the plates.

<math alttext="E sub f is less than E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. The dielectric induces a field in the opposite direction of the initial field, reducing the net field magnitude.

<math alttext="E sub f equals E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. Insulators have no effect on the electric field.

<math alttext="E sub f equals E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. A dielectric constant of <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> induces a field of magnitude <math alttext="2 E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in the opposite direction of the initial field, for a net field of the same magnitude.

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub f is less than E sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. The dielectric induces a field in the opposite direction of the initial field, reducing the net field magnitude.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
